The Nazi war crimes in the territory of the USSR are very well documented and publicized. Information about them, often in gory details, was widely disseminated by Soviet propaganda in our country and across the world. A movie about Nazi crimes called Come and See by Elem Klimov, became an anti-war classic. Stalin early realized the importance of proper documentation for the purposes of propaganda and war reparations. A well-funded Extraordinary State Commission with a high-level mandate was put together when the tide of the war was about to turn at Stalingrad in November 1942. Contrary to what honorable Thierry Etienne Joseph Rotty wrote in his answer, the Commission kept amassing a great amount of documentation throughout the war until it was disbanded in 1945. The findings of the Commission were included in the acts of the Nuremberg trials, and therefore got endorsement from the Western powers. These were also used in several trials over Nazi war criminals in the USSR in 1943–46.
